title: Developing a Sustainable Platform for Entity Annotation Benchmarks

author: Ricardo Usbeck, Agile Knowledge Engineering and Semantic Web (AKSW), University of Leipzig

segmentation: So I'm Ricardo.
I present on the behalf of Mikael, who cannot be here today, an on access who is not leaving the room.
Just closing the door?
Yeah, he's responsible, so yes, the right to go.
And the motivation for this project was basically that I started in 2013 or 2012 with semantic annotation system.

So I wanted to annotate texts and link entities, knowledge bases and what I figured was well, there are a lot of approaches and there are a lot of datasets and no approach uses the same data set as the other approach and it was really cumbersome to find some reference points.

And Furthermore there as soon as we had publications identified that are related, we found out that even if we find 2 related publications and hold their experiments next to each other, there is no no overlap at all.
So we need to fix that.
Or even worse if they overlap in terms of datasets and tools, they don't have the same results, which is weird, but well.
That signs and the problem was I couldn't even repeat any of those numbers.
So either the left one or the right one.
I had the third number, and then the reviewers came and said, well, you are doing some crazy stuff.
So we needed a solution that just allows us to compare experiments in the field of entity annotation.
And this solution is gerbil, gerbil is a benchmarking system.
Basically where you can put any number of annotators in any number of datasets.

Also coming from Data hub, open source or closed source datasets sets as long as they are available via web service codes or then if format who knows Nificent natural Language Processing interchange format it who knows.
Open annotation nobody.
Oh that's not good.
Those are two standards by W3C I think which allow you to annotate the text while.
RDF data and compare it and if your annotator speaks it in your data set is in the format, then you can easily compare those what we say.
That was a.
Platform that enables you to set work, why and if or even implemented in Java, you're annotating.
System and so we put in 10 annotation systems which is like the largest benchmark we we're aware of right now as well as 11 datasets from last 10 years research.
And now you can compare them all.
And if you go to gerbil.hw.org you can see some beauty.

Full informations about that an some diagnostics as well, but that's the basic core of trouble is that we have human and machine readable data which was before always only a latest table in the PDF, so it was closed data.
You cannot do anything with it and now we provide you with the.
Inside machine readable output, so we provide you with Jason LD, which is stored in a triple store in the back end, which you can ask so you can compare overtime.
How good was an annotator at a certain point of time.
And we give you as well.
Human readable output on the web where you can access the Jason to D, which is embedded so you have now repeatable experiments that have your eyes so you can link them in your papers.
As well as you have because it's RDF data and sorry it's not my Yahoo or some other tools that have been presented here.
You have D3 JS.
Sorry I will fix that in a minute.
Graphics there where you can see how good performs each annotate on each data set and do that weekly and let's get refreshed and we have it.
Also history of it.
And you can see why do they annotate this work good or bad.

And just because we have that data, we see that some annotators can be used for large corpora in large text and others are better for tweets which are short and have only a certain number of entities.
So just to conclude and to very briefly briefly give you an idea of gerbil, but we wanted to do is we wanted to bring open science through collaboration to the field of entity annotation.
And what we presented with the easy usage so you can just need for Java rapid and you can extend it.
Currently there are 21 Co offers an collaborators on this project from Italy from Persian, from anywhere in the world like the UK and so on.

And we can provide you with diagnostics in the machine readable format, which is I think the most important thing for our field of research that if you do evaluation provided in a format that is repeatable.
And yeah as well, please visit the OK Easy Open Knowledge Extraction Challenge at East WC.
So that's going to take place on Tuesday I think and on 1st day we announce who is the winner.
So the framework code the framework got adopted already once.
And we can show you how stable those things are in our demo.
So on Tuesday morning.
So we have the most N 6 and I welcome all of you to present it.
If we don't have enough time today.
And my questions are actually to you, do you think we can have a constant or a sustainable website where we can store all?
All experiments and how long will it be stable?
So after I finish my PhD, will it be anymore there?
I do a postdoc, so maybe it will be there.
And do you think are you willing to join such an effort of also for your field of research so we can extend it for probably search question, answering, ranking, linking whatever you name it?
And do you think 1 central platform will have a future or not?
So that would be my questions to you basically, instead of you questioning me.
Well thank you.
And if there's time I show a demo.
So after configuring an experiment and so on, you can get an experiment overview which gives you basically for a certain experiment type which is like.

For example, the annotation of documents in a certain matching or those nice graphics and also we store them and give you if you look to the experiment and ID where you can look up the experiment and when was it produced with which version of the web service and so on.
So yeah, that's basically it, and I welcome you at the most and #6 on Tuesday morning.
If you're awake then.
And meet you.
OK, thank you.
